Re: Comment No.6, I think the person you refer to is Dr Donald Berwick, of Harvard, who already is the point person for the health care overhaul. His appointment, by the way, is being resisted by the GOP.

Getting rid of all the unnecessary tests would be a great start towards bringing health care costs down.
My Grandmother had a full hysterectomy 25 years ago. 7 Years ago she was forced to pay for a "panel of tests," half of which tested her ovaries and her uterine lining, which she hadn't had in some time. But she was having kidney problems, and was well past menopause but still having hot flashes (which were attributed to the kidney cancer found three years after the stupid tests that didn't test the kidneys). The docs viewed it as a necessity to test her ovaries and uterus because of her hot flashes, while then discussing her issues and concerns with her, at that point, 18 year old hysterectomy. She fought with the nurses, but they ignored her (she was told to shut up and deal with it because she didn't understand the tests). She fought with the insurance company but was told if she argued with half of the panel of tests then they wouldn't pay for any of the tests. Her doc made about three grand off her non-existant reproductive organs, only to discover that the issue wasn't the reproductive organs. She lived, barely.
My mother is being pushed around because the family has a high rate of breast cancer, but she's not being pushed to find the cancer early. Rather she's being told, at 50, that she doesn't need another mammogram until she's 60 (past the point of the earliest cancer in the family). And to top it all off, I have a genetic disorder, I'll never be covered by insurance. I cost too much on paper, even though I don't have to do anything to treat my genes, but I have an abnormal gene or two so I'm too risky.
The insurance reform is a crock, meant to pad the already thick lining of the insurance execs pockets. Fleece the US citizens because they can, and none of their cronies on the Hill will stop them. A truly sad episode of US history.

Well America, here's my dirty little secret: I live in The Netherlands. And guess what? We DO NOT have socialized medicine here.

We pay health insurance companies just like you do. There is, however, once difference. Here it is: the government actually regulates both the providers prices and the insurance corporations' premiums.

Dig this: for just $125/mo. I get free everything...dental, psych., pharm.--whatever. Last year, I had a heart attack. The paramedics came, shocked me back into life, took me to the hospital. 10 days I rested-up in the hospital...ended-up with a left stent. Cardiologist has me on five different medications. Four times a year, I'm in for testing, etc.

Not a penny extra. Every single thing is covered. Heck, I went in and had a colonoscopy just because I'm kinky.

And get this...couple of years ago? our insurance companies bought-out your insurance companies. Transamerica? that's right, it's Dutch.

So, please, Mr. & Mrs. America--understand this: your health care and insurance problems stem from just one thing: your government refuses to practice any kind of oversight or regulations on the medical, care, pharma, and insurance industries. Because of this, these industries charge just as much as they can possibly get away with, without causing violent revolution.

We aren't socialists here in Holland. We're a capitalistic democracy, just like you...it's just that our government doesn't allow corporate executives to swim in pools of money made at the sacrifice of your health. That's all it is, a salary cap on being filthy rich.

Really, your government must actually hate you--'cause it sure as heck doesn't protect you. Ha ha ha...your #1 Hey!

"Some insurance industry lobbyists say the new federal health care law is driving up premiums. But Vincent Capozzi, senior vice president for sales and customer service at Harvard Pilgrim, said that only one percentage point of the increases here was attributable to the federal law, mainly its requirement for free coverage of preventive services."

Interesting how one side of the argument gets weasel words ("Some insurance lobbyists"), but the other side gets a named and substantiated expert.

Mr. Pear, many of us count on the NYT to provide fair information that can be held up the highest journalistic standard. Sloppy framing like this does a disservice to your audience and your publication.

The new insurance legislation is almost certainly critical to the health of our citizens. Lets keep our exploration of this topic credible by offering both points of view from a human perspective. Avoiding weasel words is a basic criterion of strong journalism. Let's not depend on them to try and prove a point.

Uphold the NYT's standards of exceptional journalism. Trust in the information, and allow your audience to decide.

I just read a post here by an ill-informed right-winger who claimed that you wait 6 months for an X-ray in Canada. This disinformation is part of the right-wing noise machines disinformation campaign to scare Americans away from getting decent health insurance, like the Canadian single-payer system.

I moved to Canada from Oregon in 1970 and, thankfully, am now a participant in the Province of Ontario's single-payer healthcare system. I go to the doctor of my choice and receive the treatment he and I deem best, and pay by presenting my OHIP (Ontario Health Insurance Plan) card. The doctor's office bills the Provincial plan and I pay nothing out-of-pocket.

Whenever I have a physical and get referred, I get X-rays, blood tests, colonocopies, bone scans and whatever in a timely manner. I'm getting a knee replacement in May, and postponed it by choice so it would not interfere with my academic duties at the Community College at which I teach.

Our healthcare system costs about 10% of GNP compared to the U.S.'s 18%, we have lower infant and maternal mortality rates, longer lifespans, and Ontario was recently cited as having among the best cancer survival rates in the world. On top of all this, we have no one uninsured !!! In other words, Canadians are not a pink slip away from loss of coverage, and a medical catastrophe does not bankrupt Canadian families.

One of the big cost factors with the U.S. system is the massive bureaucracy that Big Health maintains to 1.) deny initial coverage unless you have no risk factors and 2.) deny payment for treatment received. In other words, the U.S. already has death panels, only they are in the private sector.

As well, since I turned 65 (I'm 67), Provincial drug benefits kicked in, and that, along with my coverage from work, results in my prescription drugs costing me nothing.

So, don't believe the lies and propaganda coming out of the right-wing noise machines and toxic-talk radio. The Canadian system isn't perfect, it does have its flaws, but, all-in-all, I'll take it any day over the system currently in place in the U.S.

Americans are a wonderful, great people and they deserve much better than the healthcare system that is the highest cost model in the world and has among the lowest outcomes of any advanced economy.

The recently passed health care reform addresses health insurance coverage but does not address costs at all, as many have pointed out.
Commenter #22 recommends reading T. R. Reid's "Health Care for All: A Global Quest for Better, Cheaper and Fairer Health Care" published in the fall of 2009.
I second that recommendation wholeheartedly! Why hasn't everybody read it already?

Reid describes the health care systems in France, Germany, Japan, the UK, Canada, and Taiwan. Most of them he experienced himself in his years of living abroad as a journalist with this family. They all are better and cheaper than ours. "My global quest made it clear that the other wealthy democracies can show us how to build a decent health care system - if that's what we want....If Americans have the will to fix our costly, unfair system, the rest of the world can show us the way." p 3.

The WHO's list of the 10 best health care systems in the world (p 251-252)
France, Italy, San Marino, Andorra, Malta, Singapore, Spain, Oman, Austria, Japan. The US wasn't even close, coming in at 37th.

There are a large number of excellent examples out there in the world. Why don't we borrow examples from the best and get cracking!

I believe the new US law "restricts" the insurance companies to profits and overhead to 15%.
Wendell Potter, former head of corporate communications for CIGNA writes, "...in 2009 the five largest for-profit insurance companies...reported total profits of $12.2 billion in 2009, up 56% from the previous year."
p 144, "Deadly Spin," Wendell Potter, Bloomsbury Press, 2010.

A single-payer plan ala Canada or Medicare was not exactly rejected in 2009; Senator Baucus's (D MT) Senate Finance Committee literally laughed it out of a hearing in May or June 2009.

We're just getting started. Do the naysayers really believe that the US cannot figure out how to provide universal health care at a reasonable cost?
